name: The Ricky Gervais Guide to: Natural History

transcript.content: Hello, I'm Ricky Gervais. The English biologist Thomas Huxley once wrote: "To a person uninstructed in Natural History, his country or seaside stroll is a walk through a gallery filled with wonderful works of art. Nine-tenth of which have their faces turned to the wall. Teach him something of natural history, and you place in his hands a catalog of those which are worth turning around. To some, the wonders and intricacies of the natural world are a miracle. Living proof of the existence of God. To others the natural world is a wondrous illustration of Darwinian evolution. To discuss the complexities of plant and animal life, I'm joined by Stephen Merchant, graduate of the University of Warwick and award-winning writer.
Thank you so much for having me.
And Karl Pilkington. A man with no qualifications, very little education, but who is now known the world over as a man with a head like a fucking orange.
Alight?
Intro music

Natural history obviously takes in everything to do with animals, plants, bacteria, which are in neither group. I should start by just saying Karl, that the natural world is so diverse that we don't even know how many species there are.

Conservatively, there's two million species of animals. I mean, without even taking in plant life, there are at least 2 million species of animal. With plants and animals, there could be up to 10 million species. There are 37 thousand different species of spider alone. What do you think of that?
It's a lot.
It is, isn't it?
But if there's loads of stuff out there that we don't know about, and we don't know what it's doing, is it that important? Is it worth finding them now?
Well yeah.
Why?
Well it may give us the key to unlock other mysteries.
A spider won't.
Well it might do.
A spider won't be unlocking any mysteries.
Well, that's totally...
Plants are different. I reckon there's a natural cure for everything out there.
No. No, cause there's loads of animals that have toxins that are used in medicine.
Yeah, I know that we use dangerous spiders to get rid of headaches or whatever or they do in the tribes, right?
Yeah well
Do you want to just expand on that point?
It's just that, that's what they do in tribes.
Who's they?

All these tribes that-- they've got all natural remedies that you know, they go "What's up with you? You got a sore ankle? Chew on this twig!" And it works. I've seen it, they send women out there and like, they can't believe the stuff they can do with twigs and trees, and hedgehogs and stuff.
Mmm. It wasn't an in-depth analysis, was it?
No. Women. They just send some women out there, apparently.
I reckon the the stuff that's got venom in it, that's useful... They probably know all about them.
What do you mean? It doesn't make any sense "we probably know all about them"...
What I mean is, the police know about the gangsters.
Right

But they go "Right, we're aware of them, let them get on with it. We'll keep our eye on them." And it's the same in the jungle. These spiders-- The deadly ones, you're aware of. The ones that are just pottering about, you go "Don't even worry about them. Don't even give them a name!"
Ricky laughs
They're not doing anything.
But what if there's another poisonous spider, they have not identified yet there, lurking in the undergrowth?
I'd be very surprised.
So you'd be very surprised.
I'd be surprised if he was something
It sounds like laziness on your part.
But they're discovering new species all the time.
We know about all the dangerous stuff now because we have to. We live in a world now--
No we don't.
We do, we know about a lot of the dangerous stuff. Whenever they find something new now it's like a new butterfly or--
Well n- well no, look at AIDS.
What?
When I was a kid, I'd- no one'd ever heard of AIDS.
Yeah but that's not a natural thing, is it? That's not like a spider or a la-ladybird--
What do you mean it's not 'a natural thing'?

It's not a, it's not a natural thing. It's not something that's-- AIDS hasn't been like living under the soil for millions of years going "I'll wait till the 1980s and then come out and kill a load of people."
No, but it is a natural thing.
It's a new thing, it's new!
Yeah, yeah, but loads of animal are new, aren't they? Not in, not- I mean, in, uh, in evolutionary terms, there's new animal in evolution.

I'm sure, I'm sure there's new stuff, deep down that's just like, almost like bacteria. Sat under the soil, it'll never come to the top, right? It's like having, having an old woman who's a neighbour. She never goes out. She doesn't bother you. Let her be.
Ricky laughs
B-b-but what if that old neighbour could unlock the secrets to--
I don't think she can
-just even to us understanding th-the complexities of the universe, and the way things have developed and grown?
'Cause we'd know about it.

Well, why would we know about it? Because, I never understand, why is it you want to stop researching and studying now? Why is it that you're happy t-to to just draw a line under everything else? What if people had said this back in the 19th century?
We've done this! We've done this! I think that someone in the 1900s - we'd, uh - said everything that's going to be invented has been invented. A-and then look what happened in that century.
Yeah, and I've said to you, "Look at the stuff that is being invented now. The Frisbee and stuff like that."
Ricky and Steve laugh
It's not- right--
It's all- it's all - it's all stuff that you kind of go, "It's alright, it's a good idea but it- we don't need it."
Yeah but the Frisbee wasn't being worked on by the top brains of our generation, that was some novelty toy that some manufacturer made!

Yeah but it's like look at the fuss we made over that fella who came up with the Dyson vac'. Everyone was like "He's up there with Einstein!" Well, he's not. Now it's a good vac', it cleans up floors well and everything but--
Who said he's up there with Einstein?
His PR people?
In one of- in one of those programmes where they did like, 'Great Inventions of Our Time.' It was easy early on, you go: Einstein, y'know, Newton did this, Archimedes, Dyson.
Ricky laughs

And that's- they started to run out because it is harder to come up with something new now, because, everything that's needed-- Remember, the things we've invented are things that we sort of go, "We could do with that." Inventors don't sit there going, "What can I make? Uhh, I need a toaster." They've sat there, they've burnt the toast under the grill and they've gone "I need some sort of device here that I can put bread in..."
Well some do, yeah yeah yeah yeah yeah.
"-and what can I- ah, I'll shape it like that, yeah--"
Necessity is the mother of invention.
Yeah.
However, there are, uh, uh, people who sit around going, "W-where's a, you know, a loophole in the market where there's a little-- where's a niche?"
Well h-here's something: about a year ago, I came up with a see-through toaster so that you can see how much the toast is cooked.
Right...
Found it about two months after that, someone had done it.
Alright.
So I'd just been beaten to the post.
Yeah, but all you're really doing, Karl, is modifying an existing invention.
That's- [mumbles] what other examples of being pipped at the post are there?
Well I did--
It's got to be one that hasn't been done or it's not your theory.
But what--
But also something that unlocks
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
They're all related.
All right, but they're all related to you, but one's not so long ago, alright? And they brought 'em in and lined 'em up, and there was a chimp stood there and a gorilla.
And there's another one...
Orangutang?
Orangutang, so yeah, right. I'll go, "So the orangutan, send that out. That'll be first to go, so he's definitely not linked to me. Uh...
See, I'd disagree, but there we go, that's just looking at you.
Sort of the hair coloring. There's none of that in our family.
Well, there's no hair.
[Laughs] I like that fact that it looses out because it's ginger.
So that's gone, right? So I'm left with a gorilla and a chimp, I would go for the gorilla.
Well it was a good guess but you'd be wrong. We are much closer to the chimpanzee, okay? 98.6% genetically identical, think of that. We only differ on 1.4 percent of our genetic makeup.
Well, that-that-that must be the arse. Because that's a lot different.
Animal Rights is a hot topic.
It's a big issue.

What rights should they have? How do they compare to humans? You know, it's a well-known fact that we test on animals with the assumption that humans are more important. We test drugs on animals and we're basically saying, "If they die, they die. We'll learn something from them."
People do make distinctions between animals, right? They know that it's probably more acceptable to kill an ant than uh...
Punch a cow.
Yeah, exactly. You know it, I think that comes again from "How close are they to humans? Have they got a face? Are they furry."
Well that's the - I told, you know, about me, me Dad's mate, who had a monkey and he had to thump it.
What? One, well there's two things there, one, why did he have a monkey? Two, what sort of discipline is thumping monkey? What was the monkey doing?
It kept, it was annoying his wife a lot, and sort of, you know, pinching her ass and stuff like that.
That's not true.
Right, right, wait a minute, we've never heard this before. How have we had all these years of Monkey News and we've never heard this before?
No, Im sure I've told you about it ages ago.
Your dad had a mate that had a monkey?
Yeah, I'm sure told you.
That - why did he have a monkey? Just for a laugh?
Well, it was back in the day when people did - they all had like odd - sort of pets, didn't they?
When?
In like 'bout '68.
Oh, in 1968. Oh, when everyone had a monkey.
But he had to thump it. Now, the weird thing is though-
No, that's weird enough.
Is this the, this is all the story? This is the entire story you've got?
No-
All the information you've got is, "he had a monkey, and he had to thump it?
Yeah. My dad told me about it. When he found out that I was into monkeys he said, "Oh, Benny thumped one." and uh...

[Laughs] "Benny thumped one". "Oh, my son's into Natural History, particularly of the simian variety, I've got an interesting fact for you Karl, sit down.";"What is it Pater?"; "Um, Benny thumped one." Brilliant.
But what was interesting is, the way that, people are thumping other people all the time, no one bats an eyelid. Thump a monkey, people go, "You thumped a monkey."
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
What would you? How would you though? What would, if you wanted to make the ultimate fighting animal, what would you come up with?
If you have the power like that fella in Arabian Nights 'size of a chimpanzee', you could change into anything, but you could change into, you know, like that.
I don't think I'd go for strength and that. I'd go for survival.
What would you do, cockroach?
No, I'd have uhh. I'd have like uhhh, An armadillos body
Right, okay? So that's that, that's as big as you can be now then. So you can't really pop on a lion's head 'cause it'd just lay there going "I can't fucking move".
Alright
I'd have uh, head of an owl
Right?
Head of an owl?
Yeah. Why what come on? Why what does that bring to the table?
The heads there to sort of make it look friendly to the human race. So because if you look half decent to the human race, they'll look after you.
Right
That's the way it works, right
Okay?
Like a cat and a dog an' all that. Mmm. So the Owl makes it look nice.
Right.
I'd have uhhh, I wouldn't have legs, I'd go for like the slug juice.
Laughs. What do you mean? So now, you're a really slow moving, legless armadillo, with the head of an owl?
Slithering along. How is that gonna be friendly? They'll see the beautiful face. But then they'll be terrified by the sludge.
No, because the heads that nice, they'll, they'll forego the uh, sludge.

But hold on though. But wait a minute. So, there's got this thing that's stuck, right? Going at nought point one miles an hour. With it going "hoooo", right? You come over, you kick the head off. How is this?
No, Because the head can go into the thing like a tortoise
Can it?
Yeah. Course it can, into the armadillo body.
Well no, an armadillo doesn't do that. It just curls up into a ball.
But this isn't an armadillo, is it?
So it's...ohh.
Why has it got the slug. Why is that so attractive?
Cause I'm thinking, what I'm thinking is, an armadillo, they're good when they're on their feet. Flip 'em. They get stuck, like a tortoise
Right
Slug stuff, keeps it down. So if anything attacks it, it's like a limpet or one of them things that can go.
Well have a limpet then
But but but it can't get anywhere, how- it can barely move it
Just go, just go and kick it, just.
What do you mean it can't get anywhere?
But how can it escape from danger, it's gonna move very slowly
Rubbish, what that's the worst animal
It can lock itself in. It'll lock itself in
Yeah, and then I just scoop it up on the sou-
You can't scoop it up. It locks itself in, if it's in danger, I'd give it peacock feathers.
Laughs. This is the worst animal I've ever heard
Why has it got peacock feathers?
Again it's just, it's just uh
This is the worst animal you- I've ever heard
Why has it got peacock feathers?
Threatening. It looks more threatening.
It does- right, that's the least threatening thing, peacock feathers. Like Danny La Rue coming at ya. There's nothing remotely scary about peacock feathers.
Yeah, to humans
Yeah?
But the humans won't be harming it because they like the owl head, people will like to have these things in the garden.
Hmm
Uhh, they eat lettuce

Laughs, They eat lettuce, they eat let- why has it got a beak? They eat lettuce, he's telling me what it's gonna eat now? The owls going "fuck that. I want a mouse". I love the fact that he's based what it eats on the fact that how it moves, a bit like a slug.
Yeah
That eat lettuce, it moves that and then it eat lettuce.
Like I said, it's not that weird. If that if that existed, if that was normal, like when you went out to empty your bin, there's one of them sliding up the wall.
Laughs
You wouldn't, you wouldn't even double take, you'd just be like "oh there's the uh, owl-head peacock feathered thing".
I don't know why it's climbing walls in an effort to find lettuce?
Yeah. Why is it climbing up that wall?
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Pleasurable.
So
But...
My pleasure, er, pleasure nerve
(Laughs)
That you talking about in my head. It lights up when I have a Twix.
I don't think it ever lights up, right? I don't think you've got a pleasure nerve
But it lights up when I have a Twix.
Right
It lights up, err... If there's something, if there's some chicken, right? It lights up if there's a...
Fuck me, what a miserable cunt he is.
You know, all all loads of things...
Chicken and Twix
That's it, that's all he lives for, hang yourself mate.
So what you're saying is; if I had that device that the rat's got, I'd just sit there wouldn't I? Hitting it, thinking "I cant be bothered going to the shop for a Twix. I'll just hit this button".

Yeah... think of this. So, aggressive is the horned frog of Argentina, that people believe that, if the Frog bites the lip of a horse, the horse will die. Actually, the Frog's mouth contains no poison. It earned its fearsome reputation because it attacks animals many times its size. What do you think of a frog attacking a horse?
It's ridiculous, I don't know what's going on.
I don't know why that would happen. Why is it getting upset with a horse? Of all the things for a frog to be like, getting cocky with, them two should never even meet!
(Laughing) Why? Why? Why?
Because it's not, I mean fights, are normally 'over' something, aren't they?
Yeah.
If you have a fight with someone, "you're in my yard" or....
Yeah.
You know, It's, it's, your fighting over something.
I love the fact that he immediately goes back to the 1930s.
Yeah.
You're in my yard!
But, a horse and a Frog. How did that disagree ...
What are they squabbling over?
I don't, I don't understand what they've got in common. I don't, I don't understand it. I bet that's only happened once, it's a rare incident, someone said "put that in a book".
(Laughs)
I can't imagine it. That that's happening a lot, that horses are being bit by frogs all over the shop.
(Laughs)

I saw this trailer... for this documentary that said er, "The man who's having a baby", and I turned on, and it's a woman... going through a sex change and she's pregnant. That's not a man having a baby. That's a woman having a beard.
Having a breakdown.

What, why is that? What? That's a con, that is pure sense.... "There's as a man, having a baby, look; world's first..." no its a woman, it's a woman, What do you think of that? What would you do? If you were a doctor and I came to you and went, "Karl, listen, I'm having a bit of a rethink of these. Er, I don't...the penis, I hate it. I hate this cock.
But what do you mean you hate it?
I hate. I don't want it there, it doesn't look right? Doesn't look right. It just sits there resting on these fucking awful testicles, that I'm going to get rid of. I want, I want this thrown away.
Yeah. Well it's you know, they're not a great look. I know that, everyone knows that, it's just the way they are.
And if we're all being honest, they're an odd design. I don't think anyone likes their own, do they?
Ricky laughs
That's why we cover 'em. They're not a great thing, are they?
Wha- that's not why we cover 'em though, is it?
It's part of it, I think. I think deep down, I mean, even if like, I know you hate the Adam and Eve thing, but even if back then he was like, "Good God, cover 'em up!"
Ricky laughs
Even he had a leaf on.
[Laughing] No, but it's... So are you thinking fundamentally then, that aesthetically, the testicles and the penis isn't as good as it could be? What would you have there instead? [Sniffs]
Well, it-it's designed that way 'cause that's the way it's got to be designed. It's more about function than, uh-
Yeah.
An-and that's, that's the thing innit - with, with modern technology--
[Mumbling] The thing is, the testicles have to be outside because they have to be a few degrees below body temperature.
Yeah.

Otherwise the sertoli cells die, which sort of feed the semen and all that. So, th-that you know, t-to be functioning and sort of like fertile, they have to be outside, which is annoying because I'd put a little ribcage round 'em like that [Ricky clicks his fingers]. I-I'd pop a ribcage round those, protect 'em. Wear a cricket box, have that built-in so you cannot get a kick in, a swift kick in the bollocks, that makes you feel sick.
No but it'd-- but it'd be better if they could sort of reverse up--
Steve laughs
In a way that they w- they w- they were hidden away, so that they were just-- then you dropped 'em. It's like, "Right, we need to cool 'em down. Be at it in about half an hour."
Yeah.
[Whooshes] Drop 'em down.

Yeah, like the gear on a, on an aeroplane. Landing gear, yeah. [Imitating a pilot] "And, uh, landing gear down and the bollocks and the cooling down." Or you can just like, just pop 'em in the fridge for 10 minutes.
It's like--
What, they could detach and you can pop them in the fridge to cool them down?
Yeah. Can you make me some breasts?
Easy.
Okay. Go on - you say 'easy,' what're you gonna do? What's your plan?
Just, uh... How do you do that? It's tablets innit?
[Laughing] No, but...
'Testerone' innit?
Ricky laughs
'Testerone'?
Toblerone. I want, yeah, I want some Toblerone.
Well, sort of pointy, pointy tits like Madonna.
Ricky laughs

Where do you stop though? Supposing I came to you and I said, uh... "Doctor, listen. Um, I like the bollocks, I like the penis, but I don't like 'em where they are. I'd... I want them, I want them in the middle of me chest. I want breasticles. Yeah? The arse? I don't like it round the back, I can't see what's going on. Pop that on the front where the bollocks were. I want my arse where I can look down and see what's going on. Can you do it?"
I think it's just easier to move the head.
Steve chuckles and Ricky explodes with laughter

Rick, I know you're a big fan of Professor Richard Dawkins, the evolutionary biologist. He wrote a book, uh, 'The Ancestor's Tale' in which he predicted a post-human world. Uh, this was his, you know, his kind of hypothesis if we were t-t-to uh... well, let me read what he's written. [Quoting] "If nuclear war destroys humanity and most of the rest of life, a good bet for survival in the short-term and for evolutionary ancestry in the long-term is rats."
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
